Technique: Causal synthesis

To expand our product line and better meet the needs of our target market, we can use the technique of causal synthesis to synthesize prompts in order to understand the underlying causes or drivers of customer demand, and to identify potential solutions. For example, we might use this technique to conduct market research and analysis, in order to identify trends and patterns in customer behavior and preferences, and to understand the factors that influence their purchasing decisions. By synthesizing prompts in this way, we can generate ideas and strategies that are more targeted and effective, and can better meet the needs of our customers.

Second best technique: Temporal synthesis

Another effective technique for expanding our product line is temporal synthesis. This involves synthesizing prompts from different points in time, in order to consider how customer needs and preferences have evolved, and how they might change in the future. For example, we might use this technique to review historical data and trends, in order to identify emerging trends and patterns that might indicate

the potential success of new products or product categories. By synthesizing prompts in this way, we can anticipate and prepare for future changes in the market, and can develop strategies that are more responsive and adaptable. Third best technique: Lateral synthesis A third technique that could be helpful in expanding our product line is lateral synthesis. This involves combining prompts in unexpected or unconventional ways, in order to spark new and innovative thinking.
